The occasion also contained an international conference on Slavic literature in France. During the conference there were many discussions on the ways in which the Serbian and Croatian literary traditions could serve as a bridge for the European literary project. The most significant among them was the conference held on 14-15th January 1959, in Paris between Srdja Trifunovic, the literary critic and leader of the Slovene Renaissance, and Jadranka Lajeva (later president-designate of the Council of Europe).

The Slovene Renaissance was a political movement and it took an active part in the formation of a new Slovenia. It was strongly in favour of the "cultural autonomy" of Slovenia, its independence from central authority.

Every NFL team plays exactly four pre-season exhibition games a year, two of which are "home" games (in other words, played in their home stadium) and two which are "away" games. The team in each of the four home "away" games plays the other team the next week and the teams play their "home" and "away" opponents the following week. Each team only plays four pre-season games, but there is a long-term schedule for each team in the preseason and postseason. Each team starts the preseason in the same week it goes onto the field for the regular season. But by 1994, Libya's economy had become virtually nonexistent. In 1991 just 10 percent of Libyans owned property. By 1994 just 6 percent did.

original: Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism. Light-dark color variation is common in the mammalian taxa. Sometimes, this color variation is determined by age variation, however, in other cases, it is determined by other factors. Selective pressures, such as ecological interactions with other populations or environmental conditions, often lead to the variation in mammalian coloration. These selective pressures favor certain colors in order to increase survival. Camouflage is thought to be a major selection pressure shaping coloration in mammals, although there is also evidence that sexual selection, communication, and physiological processes may influence the evolution of coloration as well. Camouflage is the most predominant mechanism for color variation, as it aids in the concealment of the organisms from predators or from their prey. Coat color can also be for intraspecies communication such as warning members of their species about predators, indicating health for reproductive purposes, communicating between mother and young, and intimidating predators. Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism. This variation between populations and species is one of the primary means of differentiation among mammals.

Some mammals have a large number of hairs on one side of the face, such as the mouse. Such a hair appears on the face of one or both sides of the upper lip, under the chin, and is arranged in a ring around the eyes. The hairs are dark in color and are usually small. A few mammals such as the rhesus macaque, an important research model, have very few hair follicles on one side of the face, the eyebrows.

original: Like the reptiles, birds are primarily uricotelic, that is, their kidneys extract nitrogenous waste from their bloodstream and excrete it as uric acid instead of urea or ammonia through the ureters into the intestine. Birds do not have a urinary bladder or external urethral opening and (with exception of the ostrich) uric acid is excreted along with feces as a semisolid waste. However, birds such as hummingbirds can be facultatively ammonotelic, excreting most of the nitrogenous wastes as ammonia. They also excrete creatine, rather than creatinine like mammals. This material, as well as the output of the intestines, emerges from the bird's cloaca. The cloaca is a multi-purpose opening: waste is expelled through it, most birds mate by joining cloaca, and females lay eggs from it. In addition, many species of birds regurgitate pellets. Many modern specialty matches have been devised, with unique winning conditions. The most common of these is the ladder match. In the basic ladder match, the player who makes it to the top of the ladder first wins. Some other formats of game play may also involve a ladder match, typically based on the order of draw of the players.

Some games also have a tiebreaker. Usually, a combination of tiebreakers are used, with players going back to the top of the ladder in the final and deciding game on how well they have done in the tiebreakers they have used, with the final one being the tiebreaker game.

completed: Many modern specialty matches have been devised , with unique winning conditions . The most common of these is the ladder match . In the basic ladder match , the first two players start the game as the winners , with a draw in the third round as the third rule . This is sometimes referred to as a `` winner takes all `` match . A more sophisticated form of ladder match is the triangular match . In this example , the winners start the first round as winners , and the losers start the third round . In the third round , players have a tie breaker , and if a third round draw is possible , the loser can choose , after the fourth round , any two players . Another variant is the triple ladder match . This has an open list format , with ties decided by head -to- head finishes , with the loser deciding which two to play . Sound could be stored in either analog or digital format and in a variety of surround sound formats; NTSC discs could carry two analog audio tracks, plus or minus one, while PAL-specification discs could carry three analog audio tracks, plus or minus two.

Sound was stored in the sound device. Audio signals were transmitted directly to the sound device and then encoded into a standard bit stream, which could then be decoded at the sound device. The signal could be stored on a magnetic disk or recorded on to a phonograph disc.

Because of the way these machines stored sound, some sources such as a tape may be better than others. For example, a phonograph may sound better than vinyl on some types of recordings. Jean Macfarlane founded the University of California, Berkeley's Institute of Human Development, formerly called the Institute of Child Welfare, in 1927. The Institute was designed to provide research, education and supervision to improve educational and child-rearing practices. Macfarlane was a pioneer of gender studies and a leading proponent of the feminist movement.

Over the decades, the Institute continued to evolve with Macfarlane's passing in 1976, and the Institute's faculty and affiliates became stronger. The Institute's most recent director, the feminist scholar Donna Haraway, received the 1993 American Psychological Association Award for distinguished service to psychology, as well as the 1993 American Psychological Association Women's Leadership Award.

Through its programs and fellowships, the Institute supports graduate students and undergraduate scholars in human development with opportunities for research, teaching and research training. The Institute also supports the graduate and professional schools, libraries and archives of the University of California, Berkeley.

Much of Europe had been devastated by war and its post-war political and social upheavals. Yet the British remained deeply committed to empire, as did most of the European countries. Although people often think that memory operates like recording equipment, it is not the case. The molecular mechanisms underlying the induction and maintenance of memory are very dynamic and complex. Memory is not static; it is continuously stored in our brain. The act of remembering, in the same way the act of making a record is, is an ongoing process of generating new, fresh memory and replaying it from one place to another in time-space so as to obtain a memory of something that occurred later. Memory, it should be emphasized, differs from ordinary memory, which is just remembering what you have been told, in the sense that'memory' refers to memories which represent actual events which occurred to the person at the time and which have not been forgotten by him, in the sense of being remembered only in part.

completed: Although people often think that memory operates like recording equipment , it is not the case . This means that memories are more complicated than previously thought . That is why neuro biologists have started to look into how memories work . The idea is to study how memories are formed and maintained at the level of molecular mechanisms . Scientists have just begun to understand how these principles operate and there is much work to be done. In a similar vein, the emotions and disorders theory proposes that there are emotions and disorders which result from the complex interconnections among the three dimensions of emotions described thus far. Although not necessarily exclusive, there is growing evidence in the literature to suggest that, in some cases, only one of the dimensions of emotions is considered important within the field.

The first parties were called Federalist and Republican, followed by a brief period of Republican dominance before a split occurred between National Republicans and Democratic Republicans. original: Early Modern universities initially continued the curriculum and research of the Middle Ages: natural philosophy, logic, medicine, theology, mathematics, astronomy (and astrology), law, grammar and rhetoric. The importance of humanism for changing this state-of-affairs cannot be underestimated. Once humanist professors joined the university faculty, they began to transform the study of grammar and rhetoric through the studia humanitatis. A board-only organization is a special type of nonprofit organization the bylaws are made by the board rather than elected and is controlled by officers, often the organization's president. The board of directors can adopt bylaws that override and supersede the bylaws of the membership organization.

For example, menarche (the first menstrual period of a female), or semenarche (the first ejaculation of a male) are frequent sexual defining points for many cultures. In addition to biological factors, an adolescent's sexual socialization is highly dependent upon whether their culture takes a restrictive or permissive attitude toward teen or premarital sexual activity. Restrictive cultures overtly discourage sexual activity in unmarried adolescents or until an adolescent undergoes a formal rite of passage. These cultures may attempt to restrict sexual activity by separating males and females throughout their development, or through public shaming and physical punishment when sexual activity does occur. For example, menarche (the first physical manifestation of puberty) is considered one such milestone. But as a society, we haven't always agreed on what this milestone is and how age should be measured. We continue to debate whether a teenager who is able to pull off a tuxedo or take a sip of beer is really 16 years old and, if so, whether their body is ready for those things.

original: Mary's complete sinlessness and concomitant exemption from any taint from the first moment of her existence was a doctrine familiar to Greek theologians of Byzantium. Beginning with St. Gregory Nazianzen, his explanation of the "purification" of Jesus and Mary at the circumcision (Luke 2:22) prompted him to consider the primary meaning of "purification" in Christology (and by extension in Mariology) to refer to a perfectly sinless nature that manifested itself in glory in a moment of grace (e.g., Jesus at his Baptism). St. Gregory Nazianzen designated Mary as "prokathartheisa (prepurified)." An exclusive boundary arises , for example , when a person adopts a marker for defining a shared identity or space that excludes other people . original: To maintain a high constant body temperature is energy expensive – mammals therefore need a nutritious and plentiful diet. While the earliest mammals were probably predators, different species have since adapted to meet their dietary requirements in a variety of ways. Some eat other animals – this is a carnivorous diet (and includes insectivorous diets). Other mammals, called herbivores, eat plants. A herbivorous diet includes subtypes such as fruit-eating and grass-eating. An omnivore eats both prey and plants. Carnivorous mammals have a simple digestive tract, because the proteins, lipids, and minerals found in meat require little in the way of specialized digestion. Plants, on the other hand, contain complex carbohydrates, such as cellulose. The digestive tract of an herbivore is therefore host to bacteria that ferment these substances, and make them available for digestion. The bacteria are either housed in the multichambered stomach or in a large cecum. The size of an animal is also a factor in determining diet

Neutral Sections usually consist of an earthed section of wire which is separated from the live wires on either side by insulating material, typically ceramic beads, designed so that the pantograph will smoothly run from one section to the other. The earthed section prevents an arc being drawn from one live section to the other, as the voltage difference may be higher than the normal system voltage if the live sections are on different phases and the protective circuit breakers may not be able to safely interrupt the considerable current that would flow. Most fatty acids are non-essential, meaning the body can produce them as needed, generally from other fatty acids and always by expending energy to do so.

The best sources of fatty acids are animal fat and high-fat plant foods like coconut oil and flax seeds.

Fatty acids have special structures, known as fatty acid chains, in their chemical structures that can be attached to molecules of fat or other substances, such as sugars, protein, and vitamins. Thus, the essential fatty acid is actually a chain of non-essential fatty acids, made up of chains of alternating fatty acid chains.

Essential fatty acids are considered to be nutrients essential to a healthy body and mind, whereas non-essential fatty acids can be included in any of the normal food groups in a diet. Many Londoners, living in unassuming tenements with little protection, sought their own escape routes. They built underground shelters at the base of apartment buildings, or in their garages, often as temporary measures during the Blitz, only to have them quickly stripped by the authorities during the bombing. By the end of the war, they had taken more than 300,000 lives during the Blitz—more than all German combat deaths.[1]

Truman's order required all military members to establish and maintain radio stations, to receive regular transmissions from Army units operating in various theaters of operation, to transmit such transmissions, and, of course, to transmit them, not only as a military broadcast but also for their general dissemination through civilian stations and wire services. Despite the war efforts, the radio broadcast service proved to be less efficient than the wire service. original: Communication within peer groups allows adolescents to explore their feelings and identity as well as develop and evaluate their social skills. Peer groups offer members the opportunity to develop social skills such as empathy, sharing, and leadership. Adolescents choose peer groups based on characteristics similarly found in themselves. By utilizing these relationships, adolescents become more accepting of who they are becoming. Group norms and values are incorporated into an adolescent’s own self-concept. Through developing new communication skills and reflecting upon those of their peers, as well as self-opinions and values, an adolescent can share and express emotions and other concerns without fear of rejection or judgment. Peer groups can have positive influences on an individual, such as on academic motivation and performance. However, while peers may facilitate social development for one another they may also hinder it. Chapter XI deals with evidence from biogeography, starting with the observation that differences in flora and fauna from separate regions cannot be explained by environmental differences. Instead, the study of geography shows that, like a fingerprint, the flora and fauna of a region can be predicted for a range of environmental conditions due to the effect of topography and the climate on plant and animal populations. For example, in the New World tropics, most mammal species live in dense forests, with few plants and a low biodiversity. Many areas in North America have similar topographical conditions, but tropical rodents are found nowhere, while carnivores are found throughout the American south.

original: Plumage is regularly moulted; the standard plumage of a bird that has moulted after breeding is known as the "non-breeding" plumage, or—in the Humphrey-Parkes terminology—"basic" plumage; breeding plumages or variations of the basic plumage are known under the Humphrey-Parkes system as "alternate" plumages. Moulting is annual in most species, although some may have two moults a year, and large birds of prey may moult only once every few years. Moulting patterns vary across species. In passerines, flight feathers are replaced one at a time with the innermost primary being the first. When the fifth of sixth primary is replaced, the outermost tertiaries begin to drop. After the innermost tertiaries are moulted, the secondaries starting from the innermost begin to drop and this proceeds to the outer feathers (centrifugal moult). The greater primary coverts are moulted in synchrony with the primary that they overlap.

It is thought that after breeding the sexes develop different plumage, because in early development, all other parts of the bird are covered with the same feather cells.

However, not all parts of the plumage are equally important in survival. The beak is thought to be one of the most important parts in pre-breeding plumage because of the importance of a beak to feeding, and to helping a bird keep a balance in balance between itself and the environment.

original: As cellular metabolism/energy production requires oxygen, potentially damaging (e.g., mutation causing) compounds known as free radicals can form. Most of these are oxidizers (i.e., acceptors of electrons) and some react very strongly. For the continued normal cellular maintenance, growth, and division, these free radicals must be sufficiently neutralized by antioxidant compounds. Recently, some researchers suggested an interesting theory of evolution of dietary antioxidants. Some are produced by the human body with adequate precursors (glutathione, Vitamin C), and those the body cannot produce may only be obtained in the diet via direct sources (Vitamin C in humans, Vitamin A, Vitamin K) or produced by the body from other compounds (Beta-carotene converted to Vitamin A by the body, Vitamin D synthesized from cholesterol by sunlight). The phenomenalist phase of post-Humean empiricism ended by the 1940s, for by that time it had become obvious that statements about physical reality had very different implications from statements about mental objects. Physical states are no longer simply mental objects on which to pin our attention, but are rather something much deeper to be looked at in terms of what it means for a set of statements to be true or false. For instance, statements about the motion of a ship cannot be regarded as true or false because motion does not occur at all in the mind and no laws or relationships exist to connect a thought about motion with the actual motion of the ship itself.

Despite the growing appreciation of the fundamental difference between physical and mental states of affairs, the phenomenalist, despite being generally a naturalist, felt a sort of hesitance to drop his metaphysics in response to physicalism. In 1940 , the British philosopher David St ove , in his essay `` Some Mistakes we Never Make , `` gave the following account of this `` empirical turn . `` The mistake that we do make is in using physicalism as a philosophical criterion for truth , for it is the mistake we make by thinking of the physical and the logical as mutually distinct categories . `` Physicalism is simply a mistake , for the world of ideas is a world of ideas in which the physical is but one dimension of reality . original: Predators are often another organism's prey, and likewise prey are often predators. Though blue jays prey on insects, they may in turn be prey for cats and snakes, and snakes may be the prey of hawks. One way of classifying predators is by trophic level. Organisms that feed on autotrophs, the producers of the trophic pyramid, are known as herbivores or primary consumers; those that feed on heterotrophs such as animals are known as secondary consumers. Secondary consumers are a type of carnivore, but there are also tertiary consumers eating these carnivores, quartary consumers eating them, and so forth. It has a history of use that is at least 10,000 years old, and estimates of its discovery place it at 9000 BC in the Middle East; a copper pendant was found in northern Iraq that dates to 8700 BC. There is evidence that gold and meteoric iron (but not iron smelting) were the only metals used by humans before copper. The history of copper metallurgy is thought to have followed the following sequence: 1) cold working of native copper, 2) annealing, 3) smelting, and 4) the lost wax method. In southeastern Anatolia, all four of these metallurgical techniques appears more or less simultaneously at the beginning of the Neolithic c. 7500 BC. However, just as agriculture was independently invented in several parts of the world, copper smelting was invented locally in several different places. Copper occurs naturally as native copper and was known to some of the oldest civilizations on record. It has a history of use that is at least 10,000 years old, and its use in jewellery has been documented from 5000 BC. Its use in jewelry has continued into the present-day.

The most interesting thing about copper is the amount of copper it contains, and the fact that it is a metal with a fairly high melting point. Copper is a metal with an extremely large amount of energy stored in it, and the heat produced during the melting process can be used to create electricity. One of the reasons why the Romans used copper rather than iron for their weapons was the fact that copper held a higher thermal conductivity compared to iron. A high heat transfer coefficient allowed more heat to be carried away in one direction, making the metal the ideal choice for weapons.

Although this rule change has been long anticipated, some ISPs, such as Comcast and AT&T have pushed behind the scenes ever since as to how it might affect their services. To be able to sell their customers' data, the FCC will therefore need to consider a number of relevant factors.

One of these factors involves the level of privacy protection provided by a customer's "Internet service provider ("ISP")". At present, there are three different types of ISPs. There are "Title II" internet carriers (computers that transmit data using telephone lines, such as AT&T Broadband and Verizon Fios), "Title I" internet carriers (phones that transmit using telephone lines), and "ISP-less broadband internet" (which often means
completed: On 23 April 2014 , the U.S. Federal Communications Commission ( FCC ) was reported to be considering a new rule that will permit ISPs to offer content providers a direct financial transaction path to their broadband subscribers . The proposed new FCC rule ( Public Information Notice 12-06 , filed on 17 January 2014 ) would allow providers to directly provide content providers a direct financial transaction path between their subscribers and content providers over the Internet . This new proposal is known as the Direct Market Access ( D MA ) proposal. As part of its rule making process , the FCC plans to study the D MA proposal and will consider implementing the proposal through a Notice of Proposed Rule making ( NPR M ) . The D MA proposal would significantly alter the Internet broadband delivery infrastructure and would represent a policy choice for the United States . This analysis highlights the potential benefits and dangers faced by the United States if the FCC implements the D MA proposal .

The islands are at relatively low altitudes, with central Ireland and southern Great Britain particularly low lying: the lowest point in the islands is Holme, or around 80m below sea level and the highest point in Ireland, Ballyshannon, is around 350m above sea level. In contrast, the highest point in British Guiana, which is very flat over most of their range (notably on the east coast) is around 500m above sea level. The high point in Anguilla is just over 700m above sea level but is reached only in summer.

The islands are isolated from the mainland so a strong breeze or strong, northerly winds will carry the heat and humidity up from the cooler waters off the coast to much higher areas of high pressure. In some cases the invaders are causing drastic changes and damage to their new habitats (e.g.: zebra mussels and the emerald ash borer in the Great Lakes region and the lion fish along the North American Atlantic coast). Some evidence suggests that invasive species are competitive in their new habitats because they are subject to less pathogen disturbance. Others report confounding evidence that occasionally suggest that species-rich communities harbor many native and exotic species simultaneously while some say that diverse ecosystems are more resilient and resist invasive plants and animals. An important question is, "do invasive species cause extinctions?" Many studies cite effects of invasive species on natives, but not extinctions. The number of species invasions has been on the rise at least since the beginning of the 1900s. Species are increasingly being moved by humans (on farms, on islands and even through the mail), so this is not just a concern for the species themselves, but for species that we depend on for food, such as some bird species. They may not always do well in new habitats, and they can also encounter human health hazards, such as antibiotic-resistant diseases. The increase in number of invasions is a cause for concern not only for those that are impacted by these organisms, but also for a wide range of organisms that use the same water for their survival.

Why are we seeing such big numbers of species invasions across all types of habitats? The situation varies on a species level, with some species going through a burst of new invaders and others recovering from decades of sustained low numbers. How can I reduce the number of invasions I'm seeing in my local areas?

In 1877, Thomas Edison invented the phonograph. Unlike the phonautograph, it was capable of both recording and reproducing sound. Despite the huge advances made throughout the century, the technology remained somewhat inefficient. The phonautographer was expensive, prone to malfunction and would require manual adjustments due to the poor quality of microphones and speaker combinations.

In 1927, J. P. Morgan and J. W. Carnegie had the idea to combine Edison's invention with other new technologies to create the first commercial computer. To create a sound recording of the same length as a human voice, a two-inch tape was mounted with a microphone to record audio with the voice. Using a reel-to-reel player, players would play a record using an electromagnet, which would rotate the tape along with the needle, resulting in recording sound. At this level of performance, the record could be sent across the radio frequency transmission spectrum by radio receivers, effectively creating a computer.

In January 1938, Milt Gabler started recording for his new label, Commodore Records, and to allow for longer continuous performances, he recorded some 12 hours of footage each night. This was called the "Midnight Special."

In a way, it's the classic recording for its time. Though Gabler uses a more technical approach than many sound men of the time, he still makes interesting use of the microphones and his own vocal stylings to create a story and, most importantly, capture the essence of the events taking place. There is a great deal of tension and mystery built into each recording. Here, he is in a small cottage; a very dangerous place to be at night. One minute he's out front; the next, up inside his own home. There's lots of very tense moments of negotiation, some shouting and much shouting. Most memorable is a shot of a woman screaming; an event that is of great importance to the characters in Gabler's stories.
